GN   Name=pdh1 {ECO:0000303|PubMed:24970179};
OS   Agaricus xanthodermus (Poison yellow meadow mushroom).
OC   Eukaryota; Fungi; Dikarya; Basidiomycota; Agaricomycotina;
OC   Agaricomycetes; Agaricomycetidae; Agaricales; Agaricaceae; Agaricus.
OX   NCBI_TaxID=83518;
RN   [1]
RP   NUCLEOTIDE SEQUENCE [MRNA], FUNCTION, AND CATALYTIC ACTIVITY.
RC   STRAIN=CCBAS 225;
RX   PubMed=24970179; DOI=10.3390/biom3030535;
RA   Staudigl P., Krondorfer I., Haltrich D., Peterbauer C.K.;
RT   "Pyranose dehydrogenase from Agaricus campestris and Agaricus
RT   xanthoderma: Characterization and applications in carbohydrate
RT   conversions.";
RL   Biomolecules 3:535-552(2013).
RN   [2]
RP   NUCLEOTIDE SEQUENCE [MRNA] OF 26-600, PROTEIN SEQUENCE OF 26-35,
RP   FUNCTION, CATALYTIC ACTIVITY, BIOPHYSICOCHEMICAL PROPERTIES, COFACTOR,
RP   SUBCELLULAR LOCATION, SUBUNIT, GLYCOSYLATION, AND MASS SPECTROMETRY.
RC   STRAIN=CCBAS 225;
RX   PubMed=17227387; DOI=10.1111/j.1742-4658.2007.05634.x;
RA   Kujawa M., Volc J., Halada P., Sedmera P., Divne C., Sygmund C.,
RA   Leitner C., Peterbauer C., Haltrich D.;
RT   "Properties of pyranose dehydrogenase purified from the litter-
RT   degrading fungus Agaricus xanthoderma.";
RL   FEBS J. 274:879-894(2007).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Catalyzes the single-oxidation or sequential double
CC       oxidation reaction of carbohydrates primarily at carbon-2 and/or
CC       carbon-3 with the concomitant reduction of the flavin. The enzyme
CC       exhibits a broad sugar substrate specificity, oxidizing different
CC       aldopyranoses to the corresponding C-1, C-2, C-3 or C-1,2, C-2,3
CC       and C-3,4 (di)dehydro sugars with substrate-specific
CC       regioselectivity. Accepts only a narrow range of electron
CC       acceptors such as substituted benzoquinones and complexed metal
CC       ions and reacts extremely slowly with O(2) as acceptor. May play a
CC       role in the natural recycling of plant matter by oxidizing all
CC       major monosaccharides in lignocellulose and by reducing quinone
CC       compounds or reactive radical species generated during lignin
CC       depolymerization. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17227387,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:24970179}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Pyranose + acceptor = pyranos-2-ulose +
CC       reduced acceptor. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17227387,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:24970179}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Pyranose + acceptor = pyranos-3-ulose +
CC       reduced acceptor. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17227387,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:24970179}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Pyranose + acceptor = pyranos-2,3-diulose +
CC       reduced acceptor. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17227387,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:24970179}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: A pyranoside + acceptor = a pyranosid-3-ulose
CC       + reduced acceptor. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17227387,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:24970179}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: A pyranoside + acceptor = a pyranosid-3,4-
CC       diulose + reduced acceptor. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17227387,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:24970179}.
CC   -!- COFACTOR:
CC       Name=FAD; Xref=ChEBI:CHEBI:57692;
CC         Evidence={ECO:0000269|PubMed:17227387};
CC       Note=Binds 1 FAD covalently per subunit.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17227387};
CC   -!- BIOPHYSICOCHEMICAL PROPERTIES:
CC       Kinetic parameters:
CC         KM=0.78 mM for D-glucose (with ferricenium ion (Fc(+)) as
CC         electron acceptor) {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17227387};

CC         electron acceptor) {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17227387};

CC         acceptor) {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17227387};

CC         acceptor) {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17227387};

CC         electron acceptor) {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17227387};
CC         KM=17 mM for gentiobiose (with ferricenium ion (Fc(+)) as
CC         electron acceptor) {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17227387};
CC         KM=1100 uM for 1,4-benzoquinone (at pH 8.0 with D-glucose as
CC         substrate) {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17227387};
CC         KM=1040 uM for 1,4-benzoquinone (at pH 2.5 with D-glucose as
CC         substrate) {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17227387};

CC         glucose as substrate) {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17227387};

CC         glucose as substrate) {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17227387};

CC         as substrate) {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17227387};

CC         pH 10 with D-glucose as substrate)

CC         D-glucose as substrate) {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17227387};

CC         KM=50 uM for 2,6-dichloroindophenol (DCIP) (at pH 4.0 with D-
CC         glucose as substrate) {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17227387};
CC       pH dependence:
CC         Optimum pH is 7.5-9 with ferricenium ion (Fc(+)) as electron
CC         acceptor. Optimum pH values vary between 2 and 10 depending on
CC         the electron accptor (with D-glucose as substrate).
CC         {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17227387};
CC       Temperature dependence:
CC         Optimum temperature is 75 degrees Celsius with ferricenium ion
CC         (Fc(+)) as electron acceptor. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17227387};

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Catalyzes the single-oxidation or sequential double
CC       oxidation reaction of carbohydrates primarily at carbon-2 and/or
CC       carbon-3 with the concomitant reduction of the flavin. The enzyme
CC       exhibits a broad sugar substrate specificity, oxidizing different
CC       aldopyranoses to the corresponding C-1, C-2, C-3 or C-1,2, C-2,3
CC       and C-3,4 (di)dehydro sugars with substrate-specific
CC       regioselectivity. Accepts only a narrow range of electron
CC       acceptors such as substituted benzoquinones and complexed metal
CC       ions and reacts extremely slowly with O(2) as acceptor. May play a
CC       role in the natural recycling of plant matter by oxidizing all
CC       major monosaccharides in lignocellulose and by reducing quinone
CC       compounds or reactive radical species generated during lignin
CC       depolymerization. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18083263, ECO:0000269|Ref.3,
CC       ECO:0000269|Ref.4}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Pyranose + acceptor = pyranos-2-ulose +
CC       reduced acceptor. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18083263, ECO:0000269|Ref.3,
CC       ECO:0000269|Ref.4}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Pyranose + acceptor = pyranos-3-ulose +
CC       reduced acceptor. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18083263, ECO:0000269|Ref.3,
CC       ECO:0000269|Ref.4}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Pyranose + acceptor = pyranos-2,3-diulose +
CC       reduced acceptor. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18083263, ECO:0000269|Ref.3,
CC       ECO:0000269|Ref.4}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: A pyranoside + acceptor = a pyranosid-3-ulose
CC       + reduced acceptor. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18083263,
CC       ECO:0000269|Ref.3, ECO:0000269|Ref.4}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: A pyranoside + acceptor = a pyranosid-3,4-
CC       diulose + reduced acceptor. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18083263,
CC       ECO:0000269|Ref.3, ECO:0000269|Ref.4}.
CC   -!- COFACTOR:
CC       Name=FAD; Xref=ChEBI:CHEBI:57692;
CC         Evidence={ECO:0000269|PubMed:18083263,

CC       Note=Binds 1 FAD covalently per subunit.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18083263, ECO:0000269|PubMed:23326459};

CC         (Fc(+)) as electron acceptor) {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18083263};

CC         (Fc(+)) as electron acceptor) {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18083263};

CC         ion (Fc(+)) as electron acceptor) {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18083263};

CC         (Fc(+)) as electron acceptor) {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18083263};

CC         ion (Fc(+)) as electron acceptor) {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18083263};

CC         (Fc(+)) as electron acceptor) {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18083263};

CC       pH dependence:
CC         Optimum pH is 9 with ferricenium ion (Fc(+)) as electron
CC         acceptor. The enzyme is stable from pH 4 to pH 10.
CC         {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18083263};
CC       Temperature dependence:
CC         Optimum temperature is 63 degrees Celsius with ferricenium ion
CC         (Fc(+)) as electron acceptor. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18083263};

RP   PROTEIN SEQUENCE OF 26-33, FUNCTION, CATALYTIC ACTIVITY,
RP   BIOPHYSICOCHEMICAL PROPERTIES, SUBCELLULAR LOCATION, SUBUNIT, AND
RP   GLYCOSYLATION.
RC   STRAIN=D649;

RT   "Characterization of a glucose 3-dehydrogenase from the cultivated
RT   mushroom (Agaricus bisporus).";

RN   [3]
RP   FUNCTION, CATALYTIC ACTIVITY, BIOPHYSICOCHEMICAL PROPERTIES, COFACTOR,
RP   SUBSTRATE SPECIFICITY, SUBCELLULAR LOCATION, SUBUNIT, AND
RP   GLYCOSYLATION.
RC   STRAIN=Horst U3;
RX   PubMed=9133318; DOI=10.1007/s002030050424;
RA   Volc J., Kubatova E., Wood D.A., Daniel G.;
RT   "Pyranose 2-dehydrogenase, a novel sugar oxidoreductase from the
RT   basidiomycete fungus Agaricus bisporus.";
RL   Arch. Microbiol. 167:119-125(1997).
RN   [4]
RP   FUNCTION, AND CATALYTIC ACTIVITY.
RC   STRAIN=CCBAS 306;
RX   PubMed=11086703; DOI=10.1016/S0008-6215(00)00167-1;
RA   Volc J., Sedmera P., Halada P., Prikrylova V., Haltrich D.;
RT   "Double oxidation of D-xylose to D-glycero-pentos-2,3-diulose (2,3-
RT   diketo-D-xylose) by pyranose dehydrogenase from the mushroom Agaricus
RT   bisporus.";
RL   Carbohydr. Res. 329:219-225(2000).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Catalyzes the single-oxidation or sequential double
CC       oxidation reaction of carbohydrates primarily at carbon-2 and/or
CC       carbon-3 with the concomitant reduction of the flavin. The enzyme
CC       exhibits a broad sugar substrate specificity, oxidizing different
CC       aldopyranoses to the corresponding C-1, C-2, C-3 or C-1,2, C-2,3
CC       and C-3,4 (di)dehydro sugars with substrate-specific
CC       regioselectivity. Accepts only a narrow range of electron
CC       acceptors such as substituted benzoquinones and complexed metal
CC       ions and reacts extremely slowly with O(2) as acceptor. May play a
CC       role in the natural recycling of plant matter by oxidizing all
CC       major monosaccharides in lignocellulose and by reducing quinone
CC       compounds or reactive radical species generated during lignin
CC       depolymerization. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11086703,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9133318, ECO:0000269|Ref.2}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Pyranose + acceptor = pyranos-2-ulose +
CC       reduced acceptor. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11086703,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9133318, ECO:0000269|Ref.2}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Pyranose + acceptor = pyranos-3-ulose +
CC       reduced acceptor. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11086703,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9133318, ECO:0000269|Ref.2}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Pyranose + acceptor = pyranos-2,3-diulose +
CC       reduced acceptor. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11086703,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9133318, ECO:0000269|Ref.2}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: A pyranoside + acceptor = a pyranosid-3-ulose
CC       + reduced acceptor. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11086703,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9133318, ECO:0000269|Ref.2}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: A pyranoside + acceptor = a pyranosid-3,4-
CC       diulose + reduced acceptor. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11086703,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9133318, ECO:0000269|Ref.2}.
CC   -!- COFACTOR:
CC       Name=FAD; Xref=ChEBI:CHEBI:57692;
CC         Evidence={ECO:0000269|PubMed:9133318};
CC       Note=Binds 1 FAD covalently per subunit.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9133318};
CC   -!- BIOPHYSICOCHEMICAL PROPERTIES:
CC       Kinetic parameters:
CC         KM=1.83 mM for D-glucose (with 1,4-benzoquinone as electron
CC         acceptor) {ECO:0000269|Ref.2};
CC         KM=2.31 mM for D-cellobiose (with 1,4-benzoquinone as electron
CC         acceptor) {ECO:0000269|Ref.2};
CC         KM=13.8 mM for D-maltose (with 1,4-benzoquinone as electron
CC         acceptor) {ECO:0000269|Ref.2};
CC         KM=22.4 mM for L-arabinose (with 1,4-benzoquinone as electron
CC         acceptor) {ECO:0000269|Ref.2};
CC         KM=28 mM for D-xylose (with 1,4-benzoquinone as electron
CC         acceptor) {ECO:0000269|Ref.2};
CC         KM=26.1 mM for D-galactose (with 1,4-benzoquinone as electron
CC         acceptor) {ECO:0000269|Ref.2};
CC         KM=12.6 mM for sucrose (with 1,4-benzoquinone as electron
CC         acceptor) {ECO:0000269|Ref.2};
CC         KM=1.42 mM for 1,4-benzoquinone (with D-glucose as substrate)
CC         {ECO:0000269|Ref.2};
CC         Vmax=0.589 umol/sec/mg enzyme for D-glucose (with 1,4-
CC         benzoquinone as electron acceptor) {ECO:0000269|Ref.2};
CC         Vmax=0.563 umol/sec/mg enzyme for D-cellobiose (with 1,4-
CC         benzoquinone as electron acceptor) {ECO:0000269|Ref.2};
CC         Vmax=0.612 umol/sec/mg enzyme for D-maltose (with 1,4-
CC         benzoquinone as electron acceptor) {ECO:0000269|Ref.2};
CC         Vmax=0.951 umol/sec/mg enzyme for L-arabinose (with 1,4-
CC         benzoquinone as electron acceptor) {ECO:0000269|Ref.2};
CC         Vmax=0.797 umol/sec/mg enzyme for D-xylose (with 1,4-
CC         benzoquinone as electron acceptor) {ECO:0000269|Ref.2};
CC         Vmax=0.576 umol/sec/mg enzyme for D-galactose (with 1,4-
CC         benzoquinone as electron acceptor) {ECO:0000269|Ref.2};
CC         Vmax=0.235 umol/sec/mg enzyme for sucrose (with 1,4-benzoquinone
CC         as electron acceptor) {ECO:0000269|Ref.2};
CC       pH dependence:
CC         Optimum pH is 4.5. the enzyme has a second pH optimum at pH 9.
CC         {ECO:0000269|Ref.1, ECO:0000269|Ref.2};
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Monomer. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9133318, ECO:0000269|Ref.2}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Secreted {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9133318,
CC       ECO:0000269|Ref.2}. Note=Also found intracellularly in fungal
CC       hyphae. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9133318}.
CC   -!- PTM: Glycosylated. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9133318,
CC       ECO:0000269|Ref.2}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the GMC oxidoreductase family.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- CAUTION: Has been originally mistaken for cellobiose dehydrogenase
CC       (CDH) due to low activity with cellobiose. {ECO:0000303|Ref.2}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Catalyzes the oxidation of Mn(2+) to Mn(3+). The latter,
CC       acting as a diffusible redox mediator, is capable of oxidizing a
CC       variety of lignin compounds. {ECO:0000269|Ref.2}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: 2 Mn(2+) + 2 H(+) + H(2)O(2) = 2 Mn(3+) + 2
CC       H(2)O.
CC   -!- COFACTOR:
CC       Name=heme b; Xref=ChEBI:CHEBI:60344;
CC         Evidence={ECO:0000255|PROSITE-ProRule:PRU00297};
CC       Note=Binds 1 heme b (iron(II)-protoporphyrin IX) group per
CC       subunit. {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-ProRule:PRU00297};
CC   -!- COFACTOR:
CC       Name=Ca(2+); Xref=ChEBI:CHEBI:29108;
CC         Evidence={ECO:0000255|PROSITE-ProRule:PRU00297};
CC       Note=Binds 2 calcium ions per subunit. {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-
CC       ProRule:PRU00297};
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Secreted.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: By a combination of high manganese and malonate levels.
CC       {ECO:0000269|Ref.2}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the peroxidase family. Ligninase subfamily.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Shows particularly broad specificity; although bonds
CC       involving phenylalanine and leucine are preferred, many others are
CC       also cleaved to some extent.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Preferential cleavage: hydrophobic, preferably
CC       aromatic, residues in P1 and P1' positions. Cleaves 1-Phe-|-Val-2,
CC       4-Gln-|-His-5, 13-Glu-|-Ala-14, 14-Ala-|-Leu-15, 15-Leu-|-Tyr-16,
CC       16-Tyr-|-Leu-17, 23-Gly-|-Phe-24, 24-Phe-|-Phe-25 and 25-Phe-|-
CC       Tyr-26 bonds in the B chain of insulin. {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-
CC       ProRule:PRU10094}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Secreted.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the peptidase A1 family. {ECO:0000305}.

RX   PubMed=7663352; DOI=10.1002/pro.5560040516;
RA   Fujinaga M., Chernaia M.M., Tarasova N.I., Mosimann S.C.,
RA   James M.N.G.;
RT   "Crystal structure of human pepsin and its complex with pepstatin.";
RL   Protein Sci. 4:960-972(1995).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Shows particularly broad specificity; although bonds
CC       involving phenylalanine and leucine are preferred, many others are
CC       also cleaved to some extent.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Preferential cleavage: hydrophobic, preferably
CC       aromatic, residues in P1 and P1' positions. Cleaves 1-Phe-|-Val-2,
CC       4-Gln-|-His-5, 13-Glu-|-Ala-14, 14-Ala-|-Leu-15, 15-Leu-|-Tyr-16,
CC       16-Tyr-|-Leu-17, 23-Gly-|-Phe-24, 24-Phe-|-Phe-25 and 25-Phe-|-
CC       Tyr-26 bonds in the B chain of insulin. {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-
CC       ProRule:PRU10094}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Secreted.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the peptidase A1 family. {ECO:0000305}.

RP   NUCLEOTIDE SEQUENCE [MRNA].

RN   [3]
RP   CATALYTIC ACTIVITY.
RX   PubMed=7803384; DOI=10.1021/bi00255a002;
RA   Wise M.L., Hamberg M., Gerwick W.H.;
RT   "Biosynthesis of conjugated triene-containing fatty acids by a novel
RT   isomerase from the red marine alga Ptilota filicina.";
RL   Biochemistry 33:15223-15232(1994).
RN   [4]
RP   CATALYTIC ACTIVITY, AND BIOPHYSICOCHEMICAL PROPERTIES.
RX   PubMed=9062129; DOI=10.1021/bi962158v;
RA   Wise M.L., Rossi J., Gerwick W.H.;
RT   "Characterization of the substrate binding site of polyenoic fatty
RT   acid isomerase, a novel enzyme from the marine alga Ptilota
RT   filicina.";
RL   Biochemistry 36:2985-2992(1997).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Involved in the biosynthesis of conjugated triene-
CC       containing fatty acids. Catalyzes the isomerization of a wide
CC       range of substrates containing three or more methylene interrupted
CC       olefins into a Z,E,E conjugated triene functionality. May be
CC       involved in a stress tolerance mechanism as response to intertidal
CC       habitats with direct sunlight, desiccation and high temperature.
CC       In vitro substrates include arachidonic acid ((5Z,8Z,11Z,14Z)-
CC       eicosatetraenoic acid), EPA ((5Z,8Z, 11Z,14Z,17Z)-eicosapentaenoic
CC       acid), DHA ((4Z,7Z,10Z,13Z,16Z,19Z)-docosahexenoic acid), adrenic
CC       acid ((7Z,10Z,13Z,16Z)-docosatetraenoic acid), anandamide
CC       (arachidonyl-N-ethanolamide) and eicosatrienoic acid ((5Z,8Z,11Z)-
CC       eicosatrienoic acid). Gamma-linolenic acid (18:3 6Z,9Z,12Z) and
CC       dihomo-gamma-linolenic acid (20:3 8Z,11Z,14Z) are transformed into
CC       mixtures of conjugated diene and triene fatty acids, linoleic acid
CC       is only transformed to a conjugated diene.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12054482}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: (5Z,8Z,11Z,14Z,17Z)-icosapentaenoate =
CC       (5Z,7E,9E,14Z,17Z)-icosapentaenoate. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:7803384,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9062129}.
CC   -!- COFACTOR:
CC       Name=flavin; Xref=ChEBI:CHEBI:60531;
CC         Evidence={ECO:0000305|PubMed:12054482};
CC   -!- BIOPHYSICOCHEMICAL PROPERTIES:
CC       Kinetic parameters:
CC         KM=1.9 uM for (4Z,7Z,10Z,13Z,16Z,19Z)-docosahexenoic acid
CC         {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9062129};
CC         KM=17.0 uM for (7Z,10Z,13Z,16Z)-docosatetraenoic acid
CC         {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9062129};
CC         KM=9.6 uM for (5Z,8Z, 11Z,14Z,17Z)-eicosapentaenoic acid
CC         {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9062129};
CC         KM=25.5 uM for (5Z,8Z,11Z,14Z)-eicosatetraenoic acid
CC         {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9062129};
CC         KM=52.8 uM for (5Z,8Z,11Z)-eicosatrienoic acid
CC         {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9062129};
CC         KM=17.5 uM for arachidonyl-N-ethanolamide
CC         {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9062129};
CC         Vmax=1.84 umol/min/mg enzyme with (4Z,7Z,10Z,13Z,16Z,19Z)-
CC         docosahexenoic acid as substrate {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9062129};
CC         Vmax=1.1 umol/min/mg enzyme with (7Z,10Z,13Z,16Z)-
CC         docosatetraenoic acid as substrate {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9062129};
CC         Vmax=6.0 umol/min/mg enzyme with (5Z,8Z, 11Z,14Z,17Z)-
CC         eicosapentaenoic acid as substrate {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9062129};
CC         Vmax=2.78 umol/min/mg enzyme with (5Z,8Z,11Z,14Z)-
CC         eicosatetraenoic acid as substrate {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9062129};
CC         Vmax=0.31 umol/min/mg enzyme with (5Z,8Z,11Z)-eicosatrienoic
CC         acid as substrate {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9062129};
CC         Vmax=0.8 umol/min/mg enzyme with arachidonyl-N-ethanolamide as
CC         substrate {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9062129};
CC       pH dependence:
CC         Optimum pH is below pH 6.0 with (5Z,8Z,11Z,14Z,17Z)-
CC         eicosapentaenoic acid as substrate.
CC         {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9062129};
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homodimer. {ECO:0000305|PubMed:12054482}.
CC   -!- PTM: Glycosylated. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12054482}.

RP   NUCLEOTIDE SEQUENCE [MRNA] OF 25-148 (ALLELE ZF-3B), AND FUNCTION.

RP   PROTEIN SEQUENCE OF 56-63 (ALLELE ZF-3B), FUNCTION, AND CLEAVAGE AT
RP   ARG-56.
RX   PubMed=20214681; DOI=10.1111/j.1742-4658.2010.07614.x;
RA   Zanfardino A., Pizzo E., Di Maro A., Varcamonti M., D'Alessio G.;
RT   "The bactericidal action on Escherichia coli of ZF-RNase-3 is
RT   triggered by the suicidal action of the bacterium OmpT protease.";
RL   FEBS J. 277:1921-1928(2010).
RN   [6] {ECO:0000305}
RP   REVIEW.
RX   PubMed=17616268; DOI=10.1016/j.gene.2007.05.006;
RA   Pizzo E., D'Alessio G.;
RT   "The success of the RNase scaffold in the advance of biosciences and
RT   in evolution.";
RL   Gene 406:8-12(2007).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Ribonuclease. Angiogenic. Plays a role in host defense.
CC       Exhibits strong antibacterial activity against Gram-negative
CC       bacteria but mild antibacterial activity against Gram-positive
CC       bacteria. The RNase activity is not required for the bactericidal
CC       activity. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16861230,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:17347156, ECO:0000269|PubMed:18508078,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:20214681}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Secreted {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P34096}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Strongly expressed in the adult liver and gut,
CC       and weakly in the heart and testis. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17347156}.
CC   -!- DEVELOPMENTAL STAGE: Only expressed in adults.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17347156}.
CC   -!- PTM: Cleavage between Arg-55 and Arg-56 is catalyzed by a
CC       membrane-localized Gram-negative bacterium protease (OmpT in
CC       E.coli). The excised fragment is then transported to the bacterium
CC       cytosol for cleavage of the disulfide bridge linking Cys-48 and
CC       Cys-109, thus separating the N-terminal and LF-ZF3. LF-ZF3 but not
CC       the N-terminal peptide possesses bactericidal activity.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:20214681}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Although the OmpT protease is absent in Gram-
CC       positive bacteria, LF-ZF3 generated by a Gram-negative bacterium
CC       can penetrate a Gram-positive bacterium and exert its
CC       cytotoxicity. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:20214681}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the pancreatic ribonuclease family.
CC       {ECO:0000255}.

RP   X-RAY CRYSTALLOGRAPHY (2.19 ANGSTROMS) OF 19-122, SUBUNIT, AND
RP   MUTAGENESIS OF ARG-19; ARG-33; ARG-37; ARG-65; ARG-80 AND HIS-89.
RX   PubMed=24706838; DOI=10.1073/pnas.1322357111;
RA   Lu J., Yu Y., Zhu I., Cheng Y., Sun P.D.;
RT   "Structural mechanism of serum amyloid A-mediated inflammatory
RT   amyloidosis.";
RL   Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 111:5189-5194(2014).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Major acute phase protein.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homohexamer; dimer of trimers. Can form amyloid fibrils
CC       after partial proteolysis; the native, undenatured protein does
CC       not form amyloid fibrils (in vitro). Apolipoprotein of the HDL
CC       complex. Binds to heparin. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:24706838,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:7115671}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Secreted {ECO:0000269|PubMed:7115671}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed by the liver; secreted in plasma (at
CC       protein level). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12973732,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:4816450, ECO:0000269|PubMed:7115671}.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: Upon cytokine stimulation.
CC   -!- PTM: This protein is the precursor of amyloid protein A, which is
CC       formed by the removal of approximately 24 residues from the C-
CC       terminal end.
CC   -!- MASS SPECTROMETRY: Mass=11702; Mass_error=14; Method=MALDI;
CC       Range=19-122; Evidence={ECO:0000269|PubMed:12973732};
CC   -!- MASS SPECTROMETRY: Mass=11682.7; Method=MALDI; Range=19-122;
CC       Evidence={ECO:0000269|PubMed:12606051};
CC   -!- MASS SPECTROMETRY: Mass=11526.5; Method=MALDI; Range=20-122;
CC       Evidence={ECO:0000269|PubMed:12606051};
CC   -!- MASS SPECTROMETRY: Mass=11439.6; Method=MALDI; Range=21-122;
CC       Evidence={ECO:0000269|PubMed:12606051};
CC   -!- MASS SPECTROMETRY: Mass=11363.6; Method=MALDI; Range=20-121;
CC       Evidence={ECO:0000269|PubMed:12606051};
CC   -!- MASS SPECTROMETRY: Mass=11235.6; Method=MALDI; Range=20-120;
CC       Evidence={ECO:0000269|PubMed:12606051};
CC   -!- MASS SPECTROMETRY: Mass=10872.6; Method=MALDI; Range=22-119;
CC       Evidence={ECO:0000269|PubMed:12606051};
CC   -!- MASS SPECTROMETRY: Mass=8337.5; Mass_error=0.8;
CC       Method=Electrospray; Range=19-94; Note=With variants Ala-70, Val-
CC       75, Asn-78 and 86-Leu-Thr-87.;
CC       Evidence={ECO:0000269|PubMed:1463770};
CC   -!- MASS SPECTROMETRY: Mass=8390.9; Mass_error=0.2;
CC       Method=Electrospray; Range=19-94; Note=With variant Ala-70.;
CC       Evidence={ECO:0000269|PubMed:1463770};
CC   -!- POLYMORPHISM: At least 5 different SAA1 alleles have been
CC       described: SAA1.1 (SAA1alpha), SAA1.2 (SAA1beta), SAA1.3
CC       (SAA1gamma), SAA1.4 (SAA1delta), SAA1.5 (also named SAA1beta but
CC       which differs from SAA1.2). We use here the revised nomenclature
CC       described in PubMed:10211414. The sequence shown is that of
CC       SAA1.1.
CC   -!- DISEASE: Note=Reactive, secondary amyloidosis is characterized by
CC       the extracellular accumulation in various tissues of the SAA1
CC       protein. These deposits are highly insoluble and resistant to
CC       proteolysis; they disrupt tissue structure and compromise
CC       function. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:1463770}.
CC   -!- DISEASE: Note=Elevated serum SAA1 protein levels may be associated
CC       with lung cancer. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:1463770}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the SAA family. {ECO:0000305}.

DT   24-NOV-2009, sequence version 1.
DT   07-JAN-2015, entry version 16.
DE   RecName: Full=Toxin TdNa3;
DE   AltName: Full=PT-Arthr*-beta* NaTx2.4;
DE   Flags: Precursor;
OS   Tityus discrepans (Venezuelan scorpion).
OC   Eukaryota; Metazoa; Ecdysozoa; Arthropoda; Chelicerata; Arachnida;
OC   Scorpiones; Buthida; Buthoidea; Buthidae; Tityus.
OX   NCBI_TaxID=57059;
RN   [1]
RP   NUCLEOTIDE SEQUENCE [MRNA], AND PROTEIN SEQUENCE OF 21-36.
RC   TISSUE=Venom, and Venom gland;
RX   PubMed=19470401; DOI=10.1016/j.biochi.2009.05.005;
RA   D'Suze G., Schwartz E.F., Garcia-Gomez B.I., Sevcik C., Possani L.D.;
RT   "Molecular cloning and nucleotide sequence analysis of genes from a
RT   cDNA library of the scorpion Tityus discrepans.";
RL   Biochimie 91:1010-1019(2009).
RN   [2]
RP   NOMENCLATURE.
RX   PubMed=22355312; DOI=10.1371/journal.pone.0030478;
RA   Guerrero-Vargas J.A., Mourao C.B., Quintero-Hernandez V.,
RA   Possani L.D., Schwartz E.F.;
RT   "Identification and phylogenetic analysis of Tityus pachyurus and
RT   Tityus obscurus novel putative Na+-channel scorpion toxins.";
RL   PLoS ONE 7:E30478-E30478(2012).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Inhibits the sodium currents (Nav) in an apparent
CC       irreversible manner. Produces small depolarization and induces
CC       repetitive firing in squid axons. Is specific for arthropods
CC       (crickets, triatomides, crabs and squids), but is non-toxic to
CC       mice (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Secreted.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed by the venom gland.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the long (4 C-C) scorpion toxin
CC       superfamily. Sodium channel inhibitor family. Beta subfamily.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Beta toxins bind voltage-independently at site-4 of
CC       sodium channels (Nav) and shift the voltage of activation toward

CC       activation and promoting spontaneous and repetitive firing. Is
CC       toxic to arthropods (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.

CC       superfamily. Sodium channel inhibitor family. Beta subfamily.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

ID   SCNA9_TITDI             Reviewed;          85 AA.
AC   C9X4K7;
DT   20-APR-2010, integrated into UniProtKB/Swiss-Prot.
DT   20-APR-2010, sequence version 2.
DT   07-JAN-2015, entry version 17.
DE   RecName: Full=Toxin TdNa9;
DE   AltName: Full=PT-alpha* NaTx7.1;
DE   Flags: Precursor;
OS   Tityus discrepans (Venezuelan scorpion).
OC   Eukaryota; Metazoa; Ecdysozoa; Arthropoda; Chelicerata; Arachnida;
OC   Scorpiones; Buthida; Buthoidea; Buthidae; Tityus.
OX   NCBI_TaxID=57059;
RN   [1]
RP   NUCLEOTIDE SEQUENCE [MRNA], AND PROTEIN SEQUENCE OF 22-47.
RC   TISSUE=Venom, and Venom gland;
RX   PubMed=19470401; DOI=10.1016/j.biochi.2009.05.005;
RA   D'Suze G., Schwartz E.F., Garcia-Gomez B.I., Sevcik C., Possani L.D.;
RT   "Molecular cloning and nucleotide sequence analysis of genes from a
RT   cDNA library of the scorpion Tityus discrepans.";
RL   Biochimie 91:1010-1019(2009).
RN   [2]
RP   NOMENCLATURE.
RX   PubMed=22355312; DOI=10.1371/journal.pone.0030478;
RA   Guerrero-Vargas J.A., Mourao C.B., Quintero-Hernandez V.,
RA   Possani L.D., Schwartz E.F.;
RT   "Identification and phylogenetic analysis of Tityus pachyurus and
RT   Tityus obscurus novel putative Na+-channel scorpion toxins.";
RL   PLoS ONE 7:E30478-E30478(2012).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Alpha toxins bind voltage-independently at site-3 of
CC       sodium channels (Nav) and inhibit the inactivation of the
CC       activated channels, thereby blocking neuronal transmission. This
CC       toxin binds, in vitro, to sodium channels and inhibits the
CC       inactivation of the activated channels. Seems not toxic to mice,
CC       crickets and sweet-water shrimps (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Secreted.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed by the venom gland.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the long (4 C-C) scorpion toxin
CC       superfamily. Sodium channel inhibitor family. Beta subfamily.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- CAUTION: The Cys-43 indicated here is taken from the partial
CC       sequence in amino acid, and not from the translation of the
CC       transcript in which a Ser is found. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- CAUTION: This toxin sequence resembles the beta scorpion toxin
CC       class, although patch-clamp experiments shows the induction of
CC       supplementary slow inactivation of sodium channels, which means
CC       that it behaves like an alpha scorpion toxin. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -----------------------------------------------------------------------
CC   Copyrighted by the UniProt Consortium, see http://www.uniprot.org/terms
CC   Distributed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NoDerivs License
CC   -----------------------------------------------------------------------

RN   [2]
RP   NOMENCLATURE.
RX   PubMed=22355312; DOI=10.1371/journal.pone.0030478;
RA   Guerrero-Vargas J.A., Mourao C.B., Quintero-Hernandez V.,
RA   Possani L.D., Schwartz E.F.;
RT   "Identification and phylogenetic analysis of Tityus pachyurus and
RT   Tityus obscurus novel putative Na+-channel scorpion toxins.";
RL   PLoS ONE 7:E30478-E30478(2012).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Inhibits the sodium (Nav) currents in an apparent
CC       irreversible manner. Produces small depolarization and induces
CC       repetitive firing in squid axons. Is specific for arthropods
CC       (crickets, triatomides, crabs and squids), but is non-toxic to
CC       mice (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Secreted.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed by the venom gland.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the long (4 C-C) scorpion toxin
CC       superfamily. Sodium channel inhibitor family. Beta subfamily.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

ID   SCX1_TITTR              Reviewed;          84 AA.
AC   P0DMM8; A0A060BIT6;
DT   03-SEP-2014, integrated into UniProtKB/Swiss-Prot.
DT   03-SEP-2014, sequence version 1.
DT   07-JAN-2015, entry version 4.
DE   RecName: Full=Beta-mammal Tt1g;
DE   AltName: Full=T.trivittatus toxin 1 gamma-like;
DE   Flags: Precursor;
OS   Tityus trivittatus (Argentinean scorpion).
OC   Eukaryota; Metazoa; Ecdysozoa; Arthropoda; Chelicerata; Arachnida;
OC   Scorpiones; Buthida; Buthoidea; Buthidae; Tityus.
OX   NCBI_TaxID=369776;
RN   [1]
RP   NUCLEOTIDE SEQUENCE [MRNA], PROTEIN SEQUENCE OF 21-45, FUNCTION,
RP   AMIDATION AT CYS-81 LETHAL DOSE, AND MASS SPECTROMETRY.
RC   TISSUE=Venom, and Venom gland;
RX   PubMed=24862827; DOI=10.1016/j.peptides.2014.05.002;
RA   Coronas F.I., Diego-Garcia E., Restano-Cassulini R., de Roodt A.R.,
RA   Possani L.D.;
RT   "Biochemical and physiological characterization of a new Na-channel
RT   specific peptide from the venom of the Argentinean scorpion Tityus
RT   trivittatus.";
RL   Peptides 0:0-0(2014).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Beta toxins modify sodium channel function in two ways:
CC       an excitatory effect (shifting the activation process to more
CC       negative potential) and/or a depressant effect (reducing the peak
CC       current). At concentration of 500 nM this toxin produces channel
CC       opening at more negative potentials in hNav1.2/SCN2A and
CC       hNav1.3/SCN3A, which shows the biggest effect. On the other hand
CC       the peak current is decreased in hNav1.4/SCN4A and hNav1.5/SCN5A
CC       channels, without apparent modification of the activation gate.
CC       This toxin is active against mammals.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:24862827}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Secreted.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed by the venom gland.
CC   -!- MASS SPECTROMETRY: Mass=6938.12; Method=Electrospray; Range=21-81;
CC       Evidence={ECO:0000269|PubMed:24862827};
CC   -!- TOXIC DOSE: LD(50) is 28.5 ug/kg by intracranial injection into
CC       mice.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Does not produce significant modification of
CC       hNav1.1/SCN1A and hNav1.6/SCN8A currents.
CC       {ECO:0000305|PubMed:24862827}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: This toxin is thought to be responsible for the
CC       intoxication symptoms caused by the sting of this species to
CC       humans. {ECO:0000305|PubMed:24862827}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the long (4 C-C) scorpion toxin
CC       superfamily. Sodium channel inhibitor family. Beta subfamily.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

CC   Distributed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NoDerivs License

OC   Eukaryota; Metazoa; Ecdysozoa; Arthropoda; Chelicerata; Arachnida;

OX   NCBI_TaxID=6881;
RN   [1]
RP   NUCLEOTIDE SEQUENCE [MRNA], PROTEIN SEQUENCE OF 20-85, STRUCTURE BY
RP   NMR OF 20-85, FUNCTION, SUBCELLULAR LOCATION, TISSUE SPECIFICITY, MASS
RP   SPECTROMETRY, LETHAL DOSE, AND DISULFIDE BONDS.
RC   TISSUE=Venom, and Venom gland;
RX   PubMed=19631296; DOI=10.1016/j.bbapap.2009.07.006;
RA   Corzo G., Prochnicka-Chalufour A., Garcia B.I., Possani L.D.,
RA   Delepierre M.;
RT   "Solution structure of Cn5, a crustacean toxin found in the venom of
RT   the scorpions Centruroides noxius and Centruroides suffusus
RT   suffusus.";
RL   Biochim. Biophys. Acta 1794:1591-1598(2009).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Beta toxins bind voltage-independently at site-4 of
CC       sodium channels (Nav) and shift the voltage of activation toward
CC       more negative potentials thereby affecting sodium channel
CC       activation and promoting spontaneous and repetitive firing. This
CC       toxin is lethal to crustaceans (freshwater crayfish (Cambarellus
CC       montezumae spp.)), it provokes a reversible paralysis to insects
CC       (crickets (Achaeta spp.)), but is not toxic to mice. At high
CC       concentrations, it does displace the (beta) mammal-specific toxin
CC       Cn2 from rat brain synaptosomes. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:19631296}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Secreted {ECO:0000269|PubMed:19631296}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed by the venom gland.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:19631296}.
CC   -!- MASS SPECTROMETRY: Mass=7136.0; Method=Electrospray; Range=20-85;
CC       Evidence={ECO:0000269|PubMed:19631296};
CC   -!- TOXIC DOSE: LD(50) is 28.5 mg/g body weight of crayfish.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:19631296}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the long (4 C-C) scorpion toxin
CC       superfamily. Sodium channel inhibitor family. Beta subfamily.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

ID   SLA_PROJR               Reviewed;         156 AA.
AC   D1MGU0;
DT   29-MAY-2013, integrated into UniProtKB/Swiss-Prot.
DT   19-JAN-2010, sequence version 1.
DT   04-MAR-2015, entry version 24.
DE   RecName: Full=Snaclec jerdonibitin subunit alpha;
DE   AltName: Full=TJ-GPIb-bp subunit alpha;
DE   Flags: Precursor;
OS   Protobothrops jerdonii (Jerdon's pitviper) (Trimeresurus jerdonii).
OC   Eukaryota; Metazoa; Chordata; Craniata; Vertebrata; Euteleostomi;
OC   Lepidosauria; Squamata; Bifurcata; Unidentata; Episquamata;
OC   Toxicofera; Serpentes; Colubroidea; Viperidae; Crotalinae;
OC   Protobothrops.
OX   NCBI_TaxID=242841;
RN   [1]
RP   NUCLEOTIDE SEQUENCE [MRNA], PROTEIN SEQUENCE OF 24-44, FUNCTION, AND
RP   SUBUNIT.
RC   TISSUE=Venom, and Venom gland;
RX   PubMed=21256857; DOI=10.1016/j.toxicon.2011.01.010;
RA   Chen Z., Wu J., Zhang Y., Yang X., Yu G., Zhu S., Lee W., Lu Q.,
RA   Zhang Y.;
RT   "A novel platelet glycoprotein Ib-binding protein with human platelet
RT   aggregation-inhibiting activity from Trimeresurus jerdonii venom.";
RL   Toxicon 57:672-679(2011).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Snaclec that dose-dependently inhibits platelet
CC       aggregation induced by ristocetin or low-dose thrombin, but not by
CC       high-dose thrombin. Binds to GPIbalpha (GP1BA). In vivo, also
CC       dose-dependently induces thrombocytopenia of mice and platelet
CC       counts remains at very low level even after 18 hours intravenous
CC       injection. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:21256857}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Heterodimer of subunits alpha and beta; disulfide-linked.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:21256857}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Secreted.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed by the venom gland.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Does not induce platelet aggregation in either
CC       platelet rich plasma or washed platelets under high-dose
CC       conditions. Does not inhibit platelet aggregation induced by high-
CC       dose thrombin. Does not react with polyclonal anti-GPVI and anti-
CC       GPIIb antibodies (PubMed:21256857). {ECO:0000305|PubMed:21256857}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the snaclec family. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 C-type lectin domain. {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-
CC       ProRule:PRU00040}.

CC   Distributed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NoDerivs License

CC       dose-dependently induces thrombocytopenia of mice and platelet
CC       counts remains at very low level even after 18 hours intravenous
CC       injection. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:21256857}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Heterodimer of subunits alpha and beta; disulfide-linked.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:21256857}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Secreted.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed by the venom gland.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Does not induce platelet aggregation in either
CC       platelet rich plasma or washed platelets under high-dose
CC       conditions. Does not inhibit platelet aggregation induced by high-
CC       dose thrombin. Does not react with polyclonal anti-GPVI and anti-
CC       GPIIb antibodies (PubMed:21256857). {ECO:0000305|PubMed:21256857}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the snaclec family. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 C-type lectin domain. {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-
CC       ProRule:PRU00040}.

CC   Copyrighted by the UniProt Consortium, see http://www.uniprot.org/terms
CC   Distributed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NoDerivs License

RX   PubMed=24814013; DOI=10.1016/j.toxicon.2014.04.010;
RA   Jebali J., Fakhfekh E., Morgen M., Srairi-Abid N., Majdoub H.,
RA   Gargouri A., El Ayeb M., Luis J., Marrakchi N., Sarray S.;

RT   venom with anti-tumor activity against the breast cancer cell line
RT   MDA-MB231.";

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Inhibits the adhesion of MDA-MB231 human breast cancer
CC       cells to fibrinogen and fibronectin, MDA-MB231 cell migration, and
CC       the MDA-MB231 cell proliferation. This inhibition may be due to
CC       the binding to receptors of the integrin family, probably alpha-
CC       v/beta-3 (ITGAV/ITGB3) (40% inhibition of cell adhesion) and
CC       alpha-5/beta-1 (ITGA5/ITGB1) (by comparison with lebectin).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:24814013}.

CC       linked. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:24814013}.

DE   RecName: Full=Snaclec rhinocetin subunit alpha;
DE   AltName: Full=C-type lectin like protein 1;
DE   Flags: Precursor;
OS   Bitis rhinoceros (West African gaboon viper) (Vipera rhinoceros).
OC   Eukaryota; Metazoa; Chordata; Craniata; Vertebrata; Euteleostomi;
OC   Lepidosauria; Squamata; Bifurcata; Unidentata; Episquamata;
OC   Toxicofera; Serpentes; Colubroidea; Viperidae; Viperinae; Bitis.
OX   NCBI_TaxID=715877;
RN   [1]
RP   NUCLEOTIDE SEQUENCE [MRNA], PROTEIN SEQUENCE OF 24-33, FUNCTION, AND
RP   IDENTIFICATION BY MASS SPECTROMETRY.
RC   TISSUE=Venom, and Venom gland;
RX   PubMed=22689571; DOI=10.1074/jbc.M112.381483;
RA   Vaiyapuri S., Hutchinson E.G., Ali M.S., Dannoura A., Stanley R.G.,
RA   Harrison R.A., Bicknell A.B., Gibbins J.M.;
RT   "Rhinocetin, a venom-derived integrin-specific antagonist inhibits
RT   collagen-induced platelet and endothelial cell functions.";
RL   J. Biol. Chem. 287:26235-26244(2012).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Antagonist of the alpha-2 subunit of the integrin alpha-
CC       2/beta-1 (ITGA2/ITGB1) on human platelets and endothelial cells.
CC       This protein inhibits collagen-stimulated activation of human
CC       platelets in a dose-dependent manner. In addition, it antagonizes
CC       the binding of monoclonal antibodies against the alpha-2 subunit
CC       of integrin alpha-2/beta-1 to platelets and it
CC       coimmunoprecipitates with this integrin.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:22689571}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Heterodimer; disulfide-linked. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Secreted.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed by the venom gland.

DE   RecName: Full=Senecionine N-oxygenase;
DE            Short=SNO;
DE            EC=1.14.13.101;
DE   Flags: Precursor;
GN   Name=sno1;
OS   Tyria jacobaeae (Cinnabar moth).
OC   Eukaryota; Metazoa; Ecdysozoa; Arthropoda; Hexapoda; Insecta;
OC   Pterygota; Neoptera; Endopterygota; Lepidoptera; Glossata; Ditrysia;
OC   Noctuoidea; Erebidae; Arctiinae; Tyria.
OX   NCBI_TaxID=179666;
RN   [1]
RP   NUCLEOTIDE SEQUENCE [MRNA], PROTEIN SEQUENCE OF 23-60; 70-85 AND
RP   365-374, CATALYTIC ACTIVITY, AND COFACTOR.
RC   TISSUE=Larva;
RX   PubMed=11972041; DOI=10.1073/pnas.082674499;
RA   Naumann C., Hartmann T., Ober D.;
RT   "Evolutionary recruitment of a flavin-dependent monooxygenase for the
RT   detoxification of host plant-acquired pyrrolizidine alkaloids in the
RT   alkaloid-defended arctiid moth Tyria jacobaeae.";
RL   Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 99:6085-6090(2002).
RN   [2]
RP   CATALYTIC ACTIVITY, FUNCTION, COFACTOR, SUBUNIT, TISSUE SPECIFICITY,
RP   AND BIOPHYSICOCHEMICAL PROPERTIES.
RX   PubMed=9182998; DOI=10.1111/j.1432-1033.1997.00626.x;
RA   Lindigkeit R., Biller A., Buch M., Schiebel H.M., Boppre M.,
RA   Hartmann T.;
RT   "The two facies of pyrrolizidine alkaloids: the role of the tertiary
RT   amine and its N-oxide in chemical defense of insects with acquired
RT   plant alkaloids.";
RL   Eur. J. Biochem. 245:626-636(1997).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: NADPH-dependent monooxygenase that detoxifies
CC       senecionine and similar plant alkaloids that are ingested by the
CC       larvae. Is active towards a narrow range of related substrates
CC       with highest activity towards senecionine, followed by
CC       seneciphylline, retrorsine, monocrotaline, senecivernine,
CC       axillarine and axillaridine. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9182998}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Senecionine + NADPH + O(2) = senecionine N-
CC       oxide + NADP(+) + H(2)O. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11972041,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9182998}.
CC   -!- COFACTOR:
CC       Name=FAD; Xref=ChEBI:CHEBI:57692;
CC         Evidence={ECO:0000269|PubMed:11972041,
CC         ECO:0000269|PubMed:9182998};
CC   -!- BIOPHYSICOCHEMICAL PROPERTIES:
CC       Absorption:
CC         Abs(max)=456 nm {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9182998};
CC       Kinetic parameters:
CC         KM=1.4 uM for senecionine {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9182998};
CC         KM=1.3 uM for NADPH {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9182998};
CC         KM=12.5 uM for monocrotaline {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9182998};
CC       pH dependence:
CC         Optimum pH is 7.0. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9182998};
CC       Temperature dependence:
CC         Optimum temperature is 40-45 degrees Celsius.
CC         {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9182998};
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homotetramer. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9182998}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Secreted {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Hemolymph. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9182998}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Larvae store pyrrolizidine alkaloids from their
CC       host plant S.jacobaeae as non-toxic N-oxides. This serves as
CC       protection against insectivores; after ingestion of the larvae,
CC       the N-oxides are reduced in the gut of the insectivores to form
CC       toxic alkaloids (PubMed:11972041). {ECO:0000305|PubMed:11972041}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the FMO family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   Distributed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NoDerivs License

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Bifunctional enzyme involved in the biosynthesis of the
CC       phytotoxin solanapyrone, a causal agent of early blight disease of
CC       potato and tomato. Catalyzes the oxidation of prosolanapyrone II
CC       and the subsequent Diels Alder cycloisomerization of the product
CC       prosolanapyrone III to (-)-solanapyrone A.

CC       III + H(2)O(2).

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Slow-binding inhibitor of serine proteases. The
CC       inhibitor rapidly binds to the protease forming a weak enzyme-
CC       inhibitor complex, and this is followed by a slow isomerization
CC       forming a tight-binding enzyme-inhibitor complex. Active against
CC       subtilisin A with a dissociation constant of 0.18 nM. Active
CC       against perkinsin. Not active against thermolysin, papain or
CC       pepsin. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:19464375}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Secreted {ECO:0000269|PubMed:19464375}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Detected in hemolymph (at protein level).
CC       Within the digestive gland expression is limited to the basophil
CC       cells of the digestive diverticula. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:19464375}.

RP   FUNCTION, CATALYTIC ACTIVITY, AND ENZYME REGULATION.
RX   PubMed=8914083;
RX   DOI=10.1002/(SICI)1098-2795(199610)45:2<240::AID-MRD18>3.0.CO;2-4;
RA   Sawada H., Someno T.;
RT   "Substrate specificity of ascidian sperm trypsin-like proteases,
RT   spermosin and acrosin.";
RL   Mol. Reprod. Dev. 45:240-243(1996).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Trypsin-like protease with a narrow substrate
CC       specificity. Preferentially hydrolyzes substrates with Pro in the
CC       P2 position and Val in the P3 position. Plays a role in
CC       fertilization. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:6365918,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:8670234, ECO:0000269|PubMed:8914083}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Hydrolyzes arginyl bonds, preferably with Pro
CC       in the P2 position. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:6365918,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:8914083}.
CC   -!- ENZYME REGULATION: Inhibited by peptidyl-argininals wth Pro in the
CC       P2 position, diisopropyl fluorophosphate, phenylmethanesulfonyl
CC       fluoride, leupeptin, antipain, soybean trypsin inhibitor,
CC       aprotinin, ovomucoid, valyl-prolyl-arginyl-chloromethane, glycyl-
CC       valyl-arginyl-chloromethane, p-aminobenzamidine, benzamidine, zinc
CC       chloride and mercuric chloride. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:6365918,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:6381175, ECO:0000269|PubMed:8914083}.
CC   -!- BIOPHYSICOCHEMICAL PROPERTIES:
CC       Kinetic parameters:
CC         KM=145 uM for Boc-Val-Pro-Arg-MCA {ECO:0000269|PubMed:6365918};
CC       pH dependence:
CC         Optimum pH is 8.5-9.0. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:6365918};
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Heterodimer of a heavy chain and either an L1 light chain
CC       or an L2 light chain linked by a disulfide bond.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11856325}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Secreted {ECO:0000269|PubMed:8670234}.
CC       Note=Localized on the sperm head. Released into the surrounding
CC       seawater in response to the sperm reaction, a large proportion
CC       remains associated with the sperm cell surface.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:8670234}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Detected in sperm, but not in unfertilized
CC       eggs (at protein level). Expressed in gonad, but not in
CC       hepatopancreas, intestine or branchial basket.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11856325, ECO:0000269|PubMed:8670234}.
CC   -!- DEVELOPMENTAL STAGE: Expression begins about half a month before
CC       the start of the spawning season (early December), and continues
CC       throughout the spawning season. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:8670234}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the peptidase S1 family.
CC       {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-ProRule:PRU00274}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 peptidase S1 domain. {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-
CC       ProRule:PRU00274}.

DE   RecName: Full=Putative beta-neurotoxin RjAa12f {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P15226};
DE   Flags: Precursor;
OS   Rhopalurus junceus (Caribbean blue scorpion).
OC   Eukaryota; Metazoa; Ecdysozoa; Arthropoda; Chelicerata; Arachnida;
OC   Scorpiones; Buthida; Buthoidea; Buthidae; Rhopalurus.
OX   NCBI_TaxID=419285;
RN   [1] {ECO:0000305, ECO:0000312|EMBL:ADV16829.1}
RP   NUCLEOTIDE SEQUENCE [MRNA], PROTEIN SEQUENCE OF 19-82, FUNCTION,
RP   SUBCELLULAR LOCATION, TISSUE SPECIFICITY, AND MASS SPECTROMETRY.
RC   TISSUE=Venom {ECO:0000303|PubMed:21605585}, and
RC   Venom gland {ECO:0000312|EMBL:ADV16829.1};
RX   PubMed=21605585; DOI=10.1016/j.toxicon.2011.04.011;
RA   Garcia-Gomez B.I., Coronas F.I., Restano-Cassulini R., Rodriguez R.R.,
RA   Possani L.D.;
RT   "Biochemical and molecular characterization of the venom from the
RT   Cuban scorpion Rhopalurus junceus.";
RL   Toxicon 58:18-27(2011).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Beta toxins bind voltage-independently at site-4 of
CC       sodium channels (Nav) and shift the voltage of activation toward
CC       more negative potentials thereby affecting sodium channel
CC       activation and promoting spontaneous and repetitive firing. This
CC       toxin is lethal to insects (A.domestica). It is not toxic to mice
CC       and does not affect mammal F11 sodium channels.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:21605585}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Secreted {ECO:0000269|PubMed:21605585}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed by the venom gland.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:21605585}.
CC   -!- PTM: Contains 4 disulfide bonds. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:21605585}.
CC   -!- MASS SPECTROMETRY: Mass=7293.5; Method=Electrospray; Range=19-82;
CC       Evidence={ECO:0000269|PubMed:21605585};
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the long (4 C-C) scorpion toxin
CC       superfamily. Sodium channel inhibitor family. Beta subfamily.
CC       {ECO:0000255}.

DE   RecName: Full=Tetrahydrocannabinolic acid synthase;
DE            Short=THCAS;
DE            EC=1.21.3.7;
DE   AltName: Full=Delta(1)-tetrahydrocannabinolic acid synthase;
DE   AltName: Full=THCA synthase;
DE   Flags: Precursor;
OS   Cannabis sativa (Hemp) (Marijuana).
OC   Eukaryota; Viridiplantae; Streptophyta; Embryophyta; Tracheophyta;
OC   Spermatophyta; Magnoliophyta; eudicotyledons; Gunneridae;
OC   Pentapetalae; rosids; fabids; Rosales; Cannabaceae; Cannabis.
OX   NCBI_TaxID=3483;
RN   [1]
RP   NUCLEOTIDE SEQUENCE [MRNA], PROTEIN SEQUENCE OF 29-52; 330-339;
RP   426-437 AND 441-455, FUNCTION, CATALYTIC ACTIVITY, BIOPHYSICOCHEMICAL
RP   PROPERTIES, GLYCOSYLATION, AND MUTAGENESIS OF HIS-92; ARG-108;
RP   ARG-110; HIS-114 AND HIS-208.
RX   PubMed=15190053; DOI=10.1074/jbc.M403693200;

RP   NUCLEOTIDE SEQUENCE [GENOMIC DNA], AND VARIANT LEU-63.
RC   STRAIN=001, 010, 013, 020, 053, 054, and 069;
RX   PubMed=16143478; DOI=10.1016/j.forsciint.2005.07.005;
RA   Kojoma M., Seki H., Yoshida S., Muranaka T.;

RP   PROTEIN SEQUENCE OF 29-44, CATALYTIC ACTIVITY, SUBUNIT,

RT   hydrocannabinolic acid biosynthesis.";
RL   J. Am. Chem. Soc. 117:9766-9767(1995).
RN   [5]
RP   CATALYTIC ACTIVITY, AND GLYCOSYLATION.
RX   PubMed=17669365; DOI=10.1016/j.bbrc.2007.07.079;
RA   Taura F., Dono E., Sirikantaramas S., Yoshimura K., Shoyama Y.,
RA   Morimoto S.;
RT   "Production of Delta(1)-tetrahydrocannabinolic acid by the

RN   [6]
RP   X-RAY CRYSTALLOGRAPHY (2.75 ANGSTROMS) OF 28-545 IN COMPLEX WITH FAD,
RP   MUTAGENESIS OF HIS-114; HIS-292; TYR-417; GLU-442 AND TYR-484, AND
RP   DISULFIDE BOND.
RX   PubMed=22766313; DOI=10.1016/j.jmb.2012.06.030;
RA   Shoyama Y., Tamada T., Kurihara K., Takeuchi A., Taura F., Arai S.,
RA   Blaber M., Shoyama Y., Morimoto S., Kuroki R.;
RT   "Structure and function of delta(1)-tetrahydrocannabinolic acid (THCA)
RT   synthase, the enzyme controlling the psychoactivity of Cannabis
RT   sativa.";
RL   J. Mol. Biol. 423:96-105(2012).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Catalyzes the oxidative cyclization of the monoterpene
CC       moiety in cannabigerolic acid (CBGA), producing delta(9)-
CC       tetrahydrocannabinolate (THCA), the major cannabioid in drug-type
CC       Cannabis plants. Can also use cannabinerolic acid as substrate,
CC       but not cannabigerol or cannabinerol.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15190053}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Cannabigerolate + O(2) = Delta(9)-
CC       tetrahydrocannabinolate + H(2)O(2). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15190053,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:17669365, ECO:0000269|Ref.4}.
CC   -!- ENZYME REGULATION: Inhibited by Hg(2+). {ECO:0000269|Ref.4}.
CC   -!- BIOPHYSICOCHEMICAL PROPERTIES:
CC       Kinetic parameters:
CC         KM=134 uM for cannabigerolic acid {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15190053,
CC         ECO:0000269|Ref.4};
CC         KM=254 uM for cannabinerolic acid {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15190053,
CC         ECO:0000269|Ref.4};
CC         Vmax=2.68 nmol/sec/mg enzyme with cannabigerolic acid as
CC         substrate {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15190053, ECO:0000269|Ref.4};
CC         Vmax=0.37 nmol/sec/mg enzyme with cannabinerolic acid as
CC         substrate {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15190053, ECO:0000269|Ref.4};
CC         Note=kcat is 0.30 sec(-1) for cannabigerolate.;
CC       pH dependence:
CC         Optimum pH is 5.5-6.0. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15190053,
CC         ECO:0000269|Ref.4};
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Monomer. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:22766313,
CC       ECO:0000269|Ref.4}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Secreted {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16024552}.
CC       Secreted, extracellular space, apoplast
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16024552}. Note=Sorted from the secretory
CC       cells into the storage cavity of glandular trichomes.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed in the secretory cells of glandular
CC       trichomes. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16024552}.
CC   -!- PTM: Glycosylated when produced in an heterologous system. The
CC       deglycosylated THCA synthase has more catalytic activity than the
CC       glycosylated form. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15190053,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:17669365}.
CC   -!- POLYMORPHISM: Several isoforms of the active
CC       tetrahydrocannabinolic acid synthase found in the 'drug-type'
CC       cannabis plants exist due to polymorphism.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: THCA synthase might contribute to the self-defense
CC       of Cannabis plants by producing both THCA and hydrogen peroxide,
CC       but since these reaction products are toxic to the plant itself,
CC       THCA synthase must be secreted from secretory cells into the
CC       storage cavity to avoid cellular damage.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the oxygen-dependent FAD-linked
CC       oxidoreductase family. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 FAD-binding PCMH-type domain.
CC       {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-ProRule:PRU00718}.

RP   FUNCTION, TISSUE SPECIFICITY, AND GLYCOSYLATION BY PGANT3.
RX   PubMed=18835818; DOI=10.1074/jbc.M804267200;

RN   [9] {ECO:0000305}
RP   SUBCELLULAR LOCATION, TISSUE SPECIFICITY, DEVELOPMENTAL STAGE, AND
RP   GLYCOSYLATION BY PGANT3.
RX   PubMed=20371600; DOI=10.1074/jbc.M109.098145;
RA   Zhang L., Tran D.T., Ten Hagen K.G.;
RT   "An O-glycosyltransferase promotes cell adhesion during development by
RT   influencing secretion of an extracellular matrix integrin ligand.";
RL   J. Biol. Chem. 285:19491-19501(2010).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Functions as a ligand for integrin alpha-PS2/beta-PS.
CC       Required in larvae for proper muscle structure and function.
CC       Involved in the regulation of cell adhesion during wing
CC       development. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18835818,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:7924982, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9521906,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9660786}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Secreted, extracellular space, extracellular
CC       matrix {ECO:0000269|PubMed:20371600, ECO:0000269|PubMed:7924982}.
CC       Note=Localizes to the basal surface of the dorsoventral cell layer
CC       interface during pupal wing development.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:20371600, ECO:0000269|PubMed:7924982}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: In embryos, expressed in the apodemes (muscle
CC       attachment sites) of the major longitudinal muscles 4, 6, 7, 12
CC       and 13 and the wide dorsal oblique muscles 9 and 10, in hemocytes,
CC       in fat body cells, in basement membranes surrounding the gut and
CC       in the commissures of the ventral nerve cord. Expressed in larval
CC       imaginal wing disk and in pupal wing. In adult flies, expressed in
CC       the jump muscle (at protein level). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11034900,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:18835818, ECO:0000269|PubMed:20371600,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:7924982, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9521906}.
CC   -!- DEVELOPMENTAL STAGE: Expressed throughout embryogenesis; first
CC       appears at 8-10 hours. Detected in larval and pupal stages (at
CC       protein level). Transcripts are first detected at 6-8 hours of
CC       development, expression peaks at 12-14 hours and then declines by
CC       the end of embryogenesis. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:20371600,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:7924982}.
CC   -!- PTM: O-glycosylation by pgant3 is required for proper secretion
CC       and localization to the basal cell layer interface during wing
CC       development. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18835818,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:20371600}.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Pupal lethal with about 1% escapers. In
CC       mutant larvae, muscles 6 and 7 appear stringy and not anchored to
CC       other muscles or the epidermis, often these muscles are missing or
CC       unrecognizable. Sites where muscles 3, 4, 5, 8 and 16 come
CC       together are rarely recognizable and large gaps between muscles 9
CC       and 10 can be observed. Muscle contraction waves that transverse
CC       the length of the larvae and are responsible for locomotion are
CC       much slower in mutant larvae. Mutant pupae are longer than wild
CC       type pupae. Mutant adult flies present elongated abdomen and wings
CC       with altered shapes and sizes. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11034900,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9521906}.
CC   -!- SEQUENCE CAUTION:
CC       Sequence=AAQ23578.1; Type=Frameshift; Positions=1223; Evidence={ECO:0000305};

RN   [4]
RP   PROTEIN SEQUENCE OF 38-64, SIGNAL SEQUENCE CLEAVAGE SITE, SUBUNIT, AND
RP   SUBCELLULAR LOCATION.
RX   PubMed=9472029; DOI=10.1083/jcb.140.4.751;
RA   Dominguez M., Dejgaard K., Fullekrug J., Dahan S., Fazel A.,
RA   Paccaud J.P., Thomas D.Y., Bergeron J.J., Nilsson T.;
RT   "gp25L/emp24/p24 protein family members of the cis-Golgi network bind
RT   both COP I and II coatomer.";
RL   J. Cell Biol. 140:751-765(1998).
RN   [5]
RP   INTERACTION WITH STX17.
RX   PubMed=21545355; DOI=10.1042/BC20110006;
RA   Muppirala M., Gupta V., Swarup G.;
RT   "Syntaxin 17 cycles between the ER and ERGIC and is required to
RT   maintain the architecture of ERGIC and Golgi.";
RL   Biol. Cell 103:333-350(2011).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Appears to be involved in vesicular protein trafficking,
CC       mainly in the early secretory pathway. In COPI vesicle-mediated
CC       retrograde transport involved in the coatomer recruitment to
CC       membranes of the early secretory pathway. Increases coatomer-
CC       dependent activity of ARFGAP2. Thought to play a crucial role in
CC       the specific retention of p24 complexes in cis-Golgi membranes;
CC       specifically contributes to the coupled localization of TMED2 and
CC       TMED10 in the cis-Golgi network. May be involved in organization
CC       of intracellular membranes, such as of the ER-Golgi intermediate
CC       compartment and the Golgi apparatus. Involved in ER localization
CC       of PTPN2 (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Monomer and homodimer in endoplasmic reticulum.
CC       Predominantly monomeric and to lesser extent homodimeric in
CC       endoplasmic reticulum-Golgi intermediate compartment and cis-Golgi
CC       network. Probably oligomerizes with other members of the
CC       EMP24/GP25L family such as TMED2, TMED7 and TMED10. Interacts with
CC       TMED5. Interacts (via C-terminus) with COPG1; the interaction
CC       involves dimeric TMED9. Interacts with PTPN2 and SPAST (By
CC       similarity). Interacts with STX17; the interaction is direct.
CC       {ECO:0000250, ECO:0000269|PubMed:21545355,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9472029}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Q9R064:Gorasp2; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-920903, EBI-4422912;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Endoplasmic reticulum membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9472029}; Single-pass type I membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9472029}. Golgi apparatus, cis-Golgi network
CC       membrane {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9472029}; Single-pass type I membrane
CC       protein {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9472029}. Endoplasmic reticulum-Golgi
CC       intermediate compartment membrane {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9472029};
CC       Single-pass type I membrane protein {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9472029}.
CC       Golgi apparatus, trans-Golgi network membrane {ECO:0000250};
CC       Single-pass type I membrane protein {ECO:0000250}. Note=Cycles
CC       between compartments of the early secretatory pathway.
CC   -!- PTM: N-linked glycosylated containing high mannose. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the EMP24/GP25L family. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 GOLD domain. {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-
CC       ProRule:PRU00096}.

RX   PubMed=20526330; DOI=10.1038/ncb2068;
RA   Wang X., Li W., Zhao D., Liu B., Shi Y., Chen B., Yang H., Guo P.,
RA   Geng X., Shang Z., Peden E., Kage-Nakadai E., Mitani S., Xue D.;
RT   "Caenorhabditis elegans transthyretin-like protein TTR-52 mediates

RL   Nat. Cell Biol. 12:655-664(2010).
RN   [2] {ECO:0000312|EMBL:CCO25654.1}
RP   NUCLEOTIDE SEQUENCE [LARGE SCALE GENOMIC DNA].
RC   STRAIN=Bristol N2 {ECO:0000312|EMBL:CCO25654.1};
RX   PubMed=9851916; DOI=10.1126/science.282.5396.2012;
RG   The C. elegans sequencing consortium;
RT   "Genome sequence of the nematode C. elegans: a platform for
RT   investigating biology.";
RL   Science 282:2012-2018(1998).
RN   [3] {ECO:0000305}
RP   FUNCTION, AND SUBCELLULAR LOCATION.
RX   PubMed=22727702; DOI=10.1016/j.cub.2012.05.052;
RA   Mapes J., Chen Y.Z., Kim A., Mitani S., Kang B.H., Xue D.;
RT   "CED-1, CED-7, and TTR-52 regulate surface phosphatidylserine
RT   expression on apoptotic and phagocytic cells.";
RL   Curr. Biol. 22:1267-1275(2012).
RN   [4] {ECO:0000305}
RP   FUNCTION, AND INTERACTION WITH NRF-5.
RX   PubMed=22727700; DOI=10.1016/j.cub.2012.06.004;
RA   Zhang Y., Wang H., Kage-Nakadai E., Mitani S., Wang X.;
RT   "C. elegans secreted lipid-binding protein NRF-5 mediates PS
RT   appearance on phagocytes for cell corpse engulfment.";
RL   Curr. Biol. 22:1276-1284(2012).
RN   [5] {ECO:0000305, ECO:0000312|PDB:3UAF}
RP   X-RAY CRYSTALLOGRAPHY (2.01 ANGSTROMS) OF 21-135 OF MUTANT
RP   50-GLU--LEU-55, INTERACTION WITH CED-1, HOMODIMERIZATION, SUBCELLULAR
RP   LOCATION, DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE, AND MUTAGENESIS OF ASP-36; GLU-38;
RP   ASP-51; LEU-53; PRO-54; LEU-55; ARG-63; TRP-65; GLN-73; ASP-80;
RP   PRO-83; ASN-85; ARG-100; ASP-101; ILE-113; LEU-132 AND
RP   131-TYR--TYR-135.
RX   PubMed=22713871; DOI=10.1101/gad.187815.112;
RA   Kang Y., Zhao D., Liang H., Liu B., Zhang Y., Liu Q., Wang X., Liu Y.;
RT   "Structural study of TTR-52 reveals the mechanism by which a bridging
RT   molecule mediates apoptotic cell engulfment.";
RL   Genes Dev. 26:1339-1350(2012).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Plays a role as a bridging molecule that mediates
CC       recognition and engulfment of apoptotic cells by cross-linking the
CC       surface-exposed phosphatidylserine with the extracellular domain
CC       of the phagocyte receptor ced-1. Important for the generation of
CC       extracellular phosphatidylserine vesicles that promote loss of the
CC       exoplasmic leaflet from apoptotic cells in a time-dependent
CC       manner. Required for the exposure of exoplasmic leaflet on the
CC       phagocytic cells surrounding the apoptotic cells. Does not affect
CC       the phosphatidylserine externalization in living cells. May play a
CC       role in mediating transfer of phosphatidylserine from
CC       phosphatidylserine vesicles to ced-1 bearing phagocytes or
CC       alternatively result in the activation of a phosphatidylserine
CC       transporter in the phagocyte that promotes phosphatidylserine
CC       externalization. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:20526330,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:22727700, ECO:0000269|PubMed:22727702}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homodimer. Interacts with ced-1. Interacts with nrf-5.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:20526330, ECO:0000269|PubMed:22713871,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:22727700}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Secreted {ECO:0000269|PubMed:20526330,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:22713871, ECO:0000269|PubMed:22727702}. Cell
CC       surface {ECO:0000269|PubMed:20526330, ECO:0000269|PubMed:22713871,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:22727702}. Note=Detected almost exclusively on
CC       the surface of apoptotic cells. In some embryos, also observed on
CC       surface of cells adjacent to dying cells.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:20526330, ECO:0000269|PubMed:22713871,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:22727702}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed in the intestine cells.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:20526330}.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Loses ability to bind apoptotic cells and
CC       results in reduced ability of cell corpse engulfment.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:20526330, ECO:0000269|PubMed:22713871}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the nematode transthyretin-like family.
CC       {ECO:0000255}.

DT   03-APR-2013, integrated into UniProtKB/Swiss-Prot.
DT   08-MAR-2011, sequence version 1.
DT   01-APR-2015, entry version 20.
DE   RecName: Full=Toxin Acra3;
DE   Flags: Precursor;
OS   Androctonus crassicauda (Arabian fat-tailed scorpion).
OC   Eukaryota; Metazoa; Ecdysozoa; Arthropoda; Chelicerata; Arachnida;
OC   Scorpiones; Buthida; Buthoidea; Buthidae; Androctonus.
OX   NCBI_TaxID=122909;
RN   [1]
RP   NUCLEOTIDE SEQUENCE [MRNA], PROTEIN SEQUENCE OF 18-40, FUNCTION,
RP   BIOASSAY, MASS SPECTROMETRY, AMIDATION AT SER-83, SUBCELLULAR
RP   LOCATION, AND LETHAL DOSE.
RC   TISSUE=Venom, and Venom gland;
RX   PubMed=22819772; DOI=10.1016/j.peptides.2012.07.009;
RA   Caliskan F., Garcia B.I., Coronas F.I., Restano-Cassulini R.,
RA   Korkmaz F., Sahin Y., Corzo G., Possani L.D.;
RT   "Purification and cDNA cloning of a novel neurotoxic peptide (Acra3)
RT   from the scorpion Androctonus crassicauda.";
RL   Peptides 37:106-112(2012).
RN   [2]
RP   FUNCTION.
RC   TISSUE=Venom;
RX   PubMed=24055552; DOI=10.1016/j.toxicon.2013.09.009;
RA   Caliskan F., Ergene E., Sogut I., Hatipoglu I., Basalp A., Sivas H.,
RA   Kanbak G.;
RT   "Biological assays on the effects of Acra3 peptide from Turkish
RT   scorpion Androctonus crassicauda venom on a mouse brain tumor cell
RT   line (BC3H1) and production of specific monoclonal antibodies.";
RL   Toxicon 76:350-361(2013).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: The molecular target of Acra3 remains undiscovered. In
CC       vivo, induces severe neurotoxic events in mice such as
CC       excitability and convulsions, leading to the death of the animals
CC       within a few minutes after injection. Does not show toxicity in
CC       insects and crustaceans (PubMed:22819772). Exerts very strong
CC       cytotoxic effect on a mouse brain tumor cell line (BC3H1) with an
CC       IC(50) value of 5 mg/ml. It exerts its effects by inducing a
CC       stronger necrosis than apoptosis in BC3H1 cells (PubMed:24055552).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:22819772, ECO:0000269|PubMed:24055552}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Secreted {ECO:0000269|PubMed:22819772}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed by the venom gland. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- MASS SPECTROMETRY: Mass=7620.3; Method=Electrospray; Range=18-83;
CC       Evidence={ECO:0000269|PubMed:22819772};
CC   -!- TOXIC DOSE: LD(50) is less than 25 ug/kg in mouse by intracranial
CC       injection. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:22819772}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Does not inhibit Nav1.1/SCN1A, Nav1.2/SCN2A,
CC       Nav1.3/SCN3A, Nav1.4/SCN4A, Nav1.5/SCN5A, and Nav1.6/SCN8A
CC       voltage-gated sodium channels. {ECO:0000305|PubMed:22819772}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the long (4 C-C) scorpion toxin
CC       superfamily. Sodium channel inhibitor family. Beta subfamily.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

CC       amplitude by only 25% and even at concentrations up to 5 uM, the
CC       toxin does not inhibit all potassium currents. Shows signs of
CC       neurotoxicity including twitching, paralysis, and body
CC       contraction. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:22595790}.

CC       to 24.1 mg/kg in mealworms. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:22595790}.

RN   [1]
RP   NUCLEOTIDE SEQUENCE [MRNA], PROTEIN SEQUENCE OF 23-33; 729-733 AND
RP   1260-1268, FUNCTION, AND IDENTIFICATION BY MASS SPECTROMETRY.
RC   TISSUE=Venom, and Venom gland;

RA   Zeng L., Sun Q.Y., Jin Y., Zhang Y., Lee W.H., Zhang Y.;
RT   "Molecular cloning and characterization of a complement-depleting
RT   factor from king cobra, Ophiophagus hannah.";
RL   Toxicon 60:290-301(2012).
RN   [2]
RP   IDENTIFICATION BY MASS SPECTROMETRY.
RC   TISSUE=Venom;
RX   PubMed=24297900; DOI=10.1073/pnas.1314702110;
RA   Vonk F.J., Casewell N.R., Henkel C.V., Heimberg A.M., Jansen H.J.,
RA   McCleary R.J., Kerkkamp H.M., Vos R.A., Guerreiro I., Calvete J.J.,
RA   Wuster W., Woods A.E., Logan J.M., Harrison R.A., Castoe T.A.,
RA   de Koning A.P., Pollock D.D., Yandell M., Calderon D., Renjifo C.,
RA   Currier R.B., Salgado D., Pla D., Sanz L., Hyder A.S., Ribeiro J.M.,
RA   Arntzen J.W., van den Thillart G.E., Boetzer M., Pirovano W.,
RA   Dirks R.P., Spaink H.P., Duboule D., McGlinn E., Kini R.M.,
RA   Richardson M.K.;
RT   "The king cobra genome reveals dynamic gene evolution and adaptation
RT   in the snake venom system.";
RL   Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 110:20651-20656(2013).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Complement-activating protein in cobra venom. It is a
CC       structural and functional analog of complement component C3b, the
CC       activated form of C3. It binds factor B (CFB), which is
CC       subsequently cleaved by factor D (CFD) to form the bimolecular
CC       complex OVF/Bb. OVF/Bb is a C3/C5 convertase that cleaves both
CC       complement components C3 and C5. Structurally, it resembles the
CC       C3b degradation product C3c, which is not able to form a C3/C5
CC       convertase. Unlike C3b/Bb, OVF/Bb is a stable complex and
CC       completely resistant to the actions of complement regulatory
CC       factors H (CFH) and I (CFI). Therefore, OVF continuously activates
CC       complement (By similarity). As a result, OVF exhibits complement-
CC       depleting activity. {ECO:0000250, ECO:0000269|PubMed:22561424}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Heterotrimer of alpha, beta and gamma chains; disulfide-
CC       linked. May be active with factor B in the presence of factor D.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Secreted.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed by the venom gland.
CC   -!- PTM: First processed by the removal of 4 Arg residues by furin-
CC       type protease, forming two chains, alpha and gamma/beta precursor,
CC       linked by a disulfide bond. Probably, a cobrin-like protease
CC       cleaves the C3a-like domain and then the C3d-like domain,
CC       generating the mature venom factor (OVF) (By similarity).
CC       {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- PTM: The beta chain is not glycosylated.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:22561424}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the venom complement C3 homolog family.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 anaphylatoxin-like domain.
CC       {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-ProRule:PRU00022}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 NTR domain. {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-
CC       ProRule:PRU00295}.
CC   -----------------------------------------------------------------------
CC   Copyrighted by the UniProt Consortium, see http://www.uniprot.org/terms
CC   Distributed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NoDerivs License
CC   -----------------------------------------------------------------------

OS   Cotesia rubecula (Cabbage white butterfly parasite) (Apanteles
OS   rubecula).
OC   Eukaryota; Metazoa; Ecdysozoa; Arthropoda; Hexapoda; Insecta;
OC   Pterygota; Neoptera; Endopterygota; Hymenoptera; Apocrita;
OC   Ichneumonoidea; Braconidae; Microgastrinae; Cotesia.
OX   NCBI_TaxID=32392;
RN   [1]
RP   NUCLEOTIDE SEQUENCE [MRNA], PROTEIN SEQUENCE OF 24-59, FUNCTION,
RP   SUBCELLULAR LOCATION, TISSUE SPECIFICITY, AND MASS SPECTROMETRY.
RC   TISSUE=Venom, and Venom gland;
RX   PubMed=12761876; DOI=10.1002/arch.10088;
RA   Asgari S., Zareie R., Zhang G., Schmidt O.;
RT   "Isolation and characterization of a novel venom protein from an
RT   endoparasitoid, Cotesia rubecula (Hym: Braconidae).";
RL   Arch. Insect Biochem. Physiol. 53:92-100(2003).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Endoparasitoid venom protein that interferes with the
CC       activation of host hemolymph prophenoloxidase. May act in
CC       conjunction with other venom proteins (such as Vn50), by
CC       competitive binding to the zymogen and thereby interrupting the
CC       enzyme. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12761876}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Secreted {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12761876}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed by the venom gland.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12761876}.
CC   -!- PTM: Contains 2 disulfide bonds.
CC   -!- MASS SPECTROMETRY: Mass=4653.9; Method=Electrospray; Range=24-65;
CC       Note=Oxidized mass.; Evidence={ECO:0000269|PubMed:12761876};
CC   -!- MASS SPECTROMETRY: Mass=4670.5; Method=Electrospray; Range=24-65;
CC       Note=Reduced mass.; Evidence={ECO:0000269|PubMed:12761876};
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: This species is an endoparasitoid, that contain
CC       symbiotic polydnaviruses (PDV) in its genome. PDVs, used to
CC       overcome the host defenses, are introduced into the body of the
CC       host larva at oviposition by the female wasp and have been shown
CC       to be essential for successful parasitism and development of the
CC       parasitoid inside the host. Interestingly, the coding region for
CC       Vn4.6 is located in the opposite direction upstream of a gene
CC       coding for a C.rubecula PDV structural protein (Crp32).

CC   Distributed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NoDerivs License

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Endo-1,4-beta-xylanase involved in the hydrolysis of
CC       xylan, a major structural heterogeneous polysaccharide found in
CC       plant biomass representing the second most abundant polysaccharide
CC       in the biosphere, after cellulose. Hydrolyzes birch-wood xylan,
CC       with a similar activity toward oat-spelt xylan. Also shows weak
CC       activities toward pNP-beta-D-cellobioside and pNP-beta-D-
CC       xylopyranoside, but no detectable activity toward carboxymethyl
CC       cellulose and pNP-beta-L-arabinofuranoside.-.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15988573}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Endohydrolysis of (1->4)-beta-D-xylosidic
CC       linkages in xylans. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15988573}.
CC   -!- BIOPHYSICOCHEMICAL PROPERTIES:
CC       pH dependence:
CC         Optimum pH is 6.0. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15988573};
CC       Temperature dependence:
CC         Optimum temperature is 70 degrees Celsius.
CC         {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15988573};
CC   -!- PATHWAY: Glycan degradation; xylan degradation.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Secreted {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15988573}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the glycosyl hydrolase 10 (cellulase F)
CC       family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC         {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15450181, ECO:0000269|Ref.3};
CC         Vmax=506 umol/min/mg enzyme toward birchwood xylan
CC         {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15450181, ECO:0000269|Ref.3};

CC         arabinoxylans {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15450181, ECO:0000269|Ref.3};

CC         Optimum pH is 3.7-4.7 for birchwood xylan.

RX   PubMed=23948468; DOI=10.1016/j.micpath.2013.07.003;
